content: Hey I thought this stuff wasn't supposed to melt styrofoam is melting my
styrofoam did I get the wrong stuff why does this keep happening like clockwork
between comments on my videos and posts to the various terrain building groups
it's like once a month somebody makes that post piece of XPS foam melted and a
picture of the Minwax fast-drying polyurethane asking if they got the
wrong stuff or if it was defective or if I lied to them I don't know what I made
the video saying that this was a great way to coat XPS foam project because it
doesn't melt it I left out one piece of information and I left that piece out
because I thought it was common knowledge but never underestimate what
people might not know first of all when I recommend you using this I recommend
it because it doesn't melt XPS foam but I'm recommending using it as a final top
coat to your project that already has some Mod Podge and some paint on it
which adds a few layers of protection making anything in this that could cause
melting pretty much irrelevant I'm not recommending this to be used on raw
styrofoam however you can I just went outside like I've tested before many
times and I sprayed this heavily with the polyurethane and it did not melt on
raw foam however for the sake of science I created these melts making the same
mistake that you are all making when you have this problem I'm tired of typing it
out and putting it in comments to these
posts so now I can link to this video the reason it isn't melting when you are
testing it on foam is because here you had enough following regular good
practices for spraying aerosol I know what you're doing you're taking
this you're taking your foam and you're spraying like two or three inches away a
heavy puddle and it starts to melt and you freak out
you don't spray things that way that's not how you do when you're
spray-painting paint or clear coats or whatever it is you don't spray it this
close best practice is twelve inches away light sweeping passes back and
forth twelve inches away this is a piece of information I left over my video
because I thought that was common knowledge it even says it on the can if
you read it to make sweeping passes from at least 12 inches away the polyurethane
does not melt foam unlike other clear coat varnishes that can however this is
an aerosol can and it still has a solvent in it and a propellant and when
you spray those chemicals evaporate and dissipate before hitting your project so
when you're from 12 inches away the acetone or similar product that is in
this dissipates before hitting the piece and it won't smell if you spray it right
up close you're not giving it time to do that and it will start melting so it's
really simple just spray lightly 12 inches away and you will not melt your
foam I promise I even in that video said that you should always test them you can
or just test it in case it's different where you are buying it but honestly
I've been using this stuff so much now that I can spend like 40 hours building
this elaborate piece grab a new can from a
store where I've never bought it before and confidently spray it on the project
I don't even test it anymore because I know this stuff works and I know it
doesn't melt as long as you spray it correctly another frustrating thing is
that along with those questions about why is it melting the foam comes a wave
of misinformation I mean this is not something that is exclusive to the
crafting community or a problem like this is just how the internet works
somebody posts a question usually there is a handful like a whole bunch of
really helpful people that give the right answer before I even come across
the post whenever you see that post there's a lot of awesome people in the
community that straight up say right away
hey you're spraying too close too heavily that's the problem just move
back it's fine answered boom done always like clockwork people start commenting
after that they didn't read the comments and they start giving inappropriate
answers that are actually just going to lead to a worse situation for the
original poster I've seen all sorts of things people saying it's because they
got the wrong stuff because the can they showed is flammable and it's because
it's flammable to melt the foam that's a weird concept a like because this is
could set on fire like it's going to melt something I mean like makes sense
the cans I use are flammable it's the correct product is supposed to be
flammable that has nothing to do with it I also we see people posting a link to
another product by Minwax which is their polycrylic water-based sealer and often
with comments saying hey this stuff is not flammable so it won't melt the foam
well your those posts are correct that the water-based polycrylic will not melt
the foam but neither will this whole urethane if used correctly anyways the
polycrylic is not flammable its water-based but
it's also not polyurethane it is an acrylic that is why it's called
polycrylic it has a small amount of polyurethane in it but it's
not the same product that being said you can use that product on your pieces and
it will work but each can will cost you a few dollars more and the actual finish
won't be quite as hard as the polyurethane if you want to spend a few
bucks more for no reason go ahead and use that product you're
also going to be risking having a coating that turns out milky on any dark
pieces but because polycrylic is meant to coat light-colored painted wood
projects it doesn't perform well on top of dark surfaces because it can dry
inconsistently and it can dry kind of cloudy so if you have the dark stone
tower and you paint it you could have bad results likely you'll be fine but
it's a risk I don't understand why you would take when you can buy a cheaper
product that works better where polycrylic is great is if you're
working out of a can and you're using it to brush on let's say you're doing some
kind of like glossy water effect polyacrylic is great because it's soap
and water cleanup so you don't have to clean your brush with like paint thinner
or mineral spirits so it's amazing for that but when you're spraying out of an
aerosol can you shouldn't have to clean anything up
if you are doing it right so I say save your money use the product that works
that I've used 100 times and thousands of people have been using in this
community with great success just spray it on from the correct distance I'm also
realizing that it might not only be people spraying it really close it might
be a combination of that and taking it right out of the package and starting to
spray and not shaking it up enough you really have to shake it up so that
the polyurethane mixes with the carrier and propellant and you just if you don't
mix this the polyurethane is going to be settled at the bottom and you're just
going to get a crazy dosage of the propellant and it's going to be a lot
harder and melt it shake it up spray its sweeping motions from a distance you're
going to be fine will melt the other thing I want to
bring up here is that every single time someone makes that post about their
stuff melting from it more than one person will post a link to the Kryon
styrofoam primer saying this won't melt foam I don't know why this always comes
up because it's like somebody is making a post on a baking community saying hey
I'm trying to make banana bread and it always turns out poorly and the reason
it's carrying will poorly is because they're not using brown bananas but then
someone comments with these apples the Krylon primer and the mineralized
polyurethane serve two entirely different purposes in the terrain
building process they are not a replacement for each other they have
nothing to do with each other if someone posts spray-painting something black or
white and it melts the foam yes the Krylon primer that's meant for foam is a
great solution to present to someone because hey this is how do you spray
paint in a way that won't melt the foam the clear coat is meant as a final step
to seal your project the last thing you do so what good would a spray on primer
be for that you're not using the Minwax to prime your project for just testing
it on raw foam so while that Krylon spray-down stuff is fine if you want to
but like white prime styrofoam with all the risk of melting that's what it's for
is enough for the same thing that the Minwax is for not even close so just to
reiterate the Minwax fast-drying polyurethane in a can if used correctly
shake it up enough before you spray it straight from 12 inches away and do
light sweeping passes I don't care how much you put on you can do a hundred
passes and just drench your piece it's not going to melt so pick the stuff up
use it but use it for what it's meant to be used for in terrain building well not
meant to be used for but like what I've discovered it's great for using which is
finishing your project clear coating it once it's done and you will be fine I
promise anyways guys I know that was a bit Randy
it's just sometimes I get frustrated when I see the same things happening
over and over and over again and the same misinformation going over and over
and over again when I feel like I've already covered it maybe I didn't cover
it well enough but now this is my definitive I'm gonna link to this when
people make those posts and video I hope that you found it helpful if you did hit
that like button drop me a comment below if you're new to the channel hit
subscribe most of my videos are more tutorial based and less berating ranting
if you want to buy some of this stuff and you want to make sure you're buying
the correct stuff you can head over to Blackmagic crafty 8 and I have links to
it through my Amazon affiliate store we'll make sure you get the correct
product and I will get a small Commission from the sale that will help
to fund this channel and future videos also if you really want to help out the
channel consider supporting me on patreon the funds from those supporters
are what makes it possible to continue this channel and I got some cool rewards
for the people to support and we're building a great patreon community so
consider checking it out till next week guys Cheers
happy crafting and may your foam stay unmelted and pure or
